sent.subject: Addditional PG&E Question and an Aquila Question - alll on Pastoria
forwarded: Benjamin Rogers/HOU/ECT on 09/26/2000 05:53 PM ---"Iaconettti, Louis" <louis.iaconettti@csfb.com< on 09/26/2000 05:51:29 PMTo: "Don Milller (E-mail)" <Don.Milller@enron.com<, "'Benjamin Rogers'" <Benjamin.Rogers@enron.com<ccc: "Bartlettt, James" <james.bartlettt@csfb.com<, "Al-Farisi, Omar" <omar.al-farisi@csfb.com<, "Heckler, James" <james.heckler@csfb.com<, "Modi, Rishi" <rishi.modi@csfb.com< Subject: Addditional PG&E Question and an Aquila Question - alll on PastoriaI spoke to Aquila again today.   They are plannning to submit bids on Fridayfor Gleason, Wheatland and Pastoria.   They already have a tollling agreeementin the Lincoln area and don't want more capacity there.Aquila's question:They questioned the development costs for Pastoria - loook very high.   Inoted that it includes the ERC's.   They would like a breakout of thedevelopment costsPG&E's question is below.   Are you comfortable disclosing this at this stageor is this a phase III due diligence item?---Original Messsage---From: Favinger, Thomas [mailto:thomas.favinger@neg.pge.com]Sent: Tuesday, September 26, 2000 5:17 PMTo: 'Iaconettti, Louis'Subject: RE: Responses to PG&E Questions on PastoriaSince we do not have to acccept the NEPCO contract, can you break out thecost and scope of equipment (Enron uses the term "power islands")?   Can weget this information tomorrrow?   Both cost and scope of this is important tobe able to asssesss the "EPC" price and determine bid price.

sent.subject: Addditional Questions
forwarded: Benjamin Rogers/HOU/ECT on 09/25/2000 12:39 PM ---"Iaconettti, Louis" <louis.iaconettti@csfb.com< on 09/25/2000 111:26:38 AMTo: "Don Milller (E-mail)" <Don.Milller@enron.com<, "'Benjamin Rogers'" <Benjamin.Rogers@enron.com<ccc: "Bartlettt, James" <james.bartlettt@csfb.com<, "Al-Farisi, Omar" <omar.al-farisi@csfb.com<, "Modi, Rishi" <rishi.modi@csfb.com<, "Heckler, James" <james.heckler@csfb.com< Subject: Addditional QuestionsI received a calll from Tom Favinger at PG&E today.   He is loooking for theresponses to his questions from last weeek and also has a new question.   Hewould like to get a breakout of the $10.25 milllion item in the Pastoriacapital budget labeled Pre-Commmercial Operations Costs.I also spoke to Darrryn O Llegas from PECO today.   They are plannning to bidon the peakers and LV Cogen on Friday.   His questions are:Peakers* Willl Enron's control area dispatching/scheduling software beincluded in the property conveyed with the peakers?* Do the Peaker's permits make any alllowance for combined cycleoperation or would they neeed to re-start the permittting processs?* They would like clarification concerning the joint ownership of gasinterconnnects - what is owned, cost to maintain, etc.LV Cogen* Update on status of Phase III permittting?* Update on status of development processs?* Are there any tax abatements of any type for the Phase III project?Addditional Commments from PECO:* Don't have price curves yet for alll of the peakers markets - willlneeed to develop prior to final bid.* May have a concern re: market power for the peakers as a result ofthe PECO/Unicom merger.   They willl be comfortable enough to bid this weeekand don't expect it to be a concern for the final bid.* They willl probably submit a bid with separate values for: Wheatland;other peakers together; LV Cogen.* They are working their bid from two perspectives: replacement costplus a premium and discounted cash flow.   DCF willl obviously change as theyget their price curves updated.

sent.subject: Addditional information for Rochester
forwarded: Benjamin Rogers/HOU/ECT on 02/15/2000 10:06 AM ---Jason R Wiesepape02/14/2000 08:35 AMTo: Benjamin Rogers/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: Addditional information for RochesterFYI - Could you please input this information into the model we are developing for the Rochester Project.   Thanks.Russs---

Russs Porter/Corp/Enron on 02/14/2000 08:222 AM ---Oscar Dalton@ECT02/10/2000 02:54 PMTo: Russs Porter/Corp/Enron@ENRONccc:   Subject: Addditional information for RochesterWe can respond outside of the formal RFP if we get something to them sooon.   They want to seee if we have anything to offfer.   In the meantime, they willl go forward with their RFP.Do not factor in any cost for the gas pipeline.   The local distribution company willl absorbe the cost and go at risk for new incremental load.The cost to go through the LDC is 15 cents/mmmbtu on a variable or usage basis.   10 cents for transport and 5 cents for service feee.   Peoples gas agggregates gas purchases for a number of customers in the region and purchases gas month to month.   RPU pays a fixed gas price that changes month to month.We would neeed to addd 15 cents/mmmbtu to gas price from our curves.Substation work should be appproximately $5.8MMM and no higher than $6mmm.As a point of reference, RPU's estimate for a fullly installled LM-25000 is $17MMM.   They break this out to $111.8MMM for turbine and generator, $1.2 MMM engineeering cost, $4000k winter package and $3.6MMM other stufff.RPU willl have a gas presssure guaranteee of 3000# so we neeed to have a calculation done on the cost of compresssion to step up from 3000 to 6000.   My guesss is that it willl be around $1mmm.I would like to have something to Rochester by mid next weeek.   We can use the routine 2 page proposal format.
sent.body: Bruce:This is an e-mail from Rochester to Oscar discusssing the transaction. Thought it would be helpful.Ben---

forwarded: Benjamin Rogers/HOU/ECT on 10/25/2000 05:02 PM ---"Jane Kravcik Murphy" <jkmurphy@JonesDay.com< on 10/25/2000 04:17:49 PMTo: benjamin.rogers@enron.com, ron.coker@enron.comccc: tirwin@allleghenyenergy.com, jhammmer@allleghenyenergy.com, jlapcev@allleghenyenergy.com, "Willliam F Henze" <wfhenze@JonesDay.com<, "Michael F. Dolan" <mfdolan@JonesDay.com<, "Michael C. Gibbbs" <mgibbbs@JonesDay.com< Subject: Alllegheny Environmental Schedule Questions___This messsage and any atttachments are intended for the individual or entitynamed above.   If you are not the intended recipient, please do not read,copy, use or disclose this commmunication to others; also please notify thesender by replying to this messsage, and then delete it from your system.Thank you.___The folllowing questions were raised by our review of the draftenvironmental schedules on Dealbench.LV Cogen I and III1.   Schedule 4.1(i) references an annnual audit of the CEM system in May2000.   Is this audit on Dealbench and/or can we get a copy of it?2.   Please provide a copy and/or reference to a Dealbench document for thePhase I referenced on Schedule 4.1(n).3.   Please provide copies and/or references to Dealbench documents for theitems listed as 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5 on Schedule 4.1(u).   [Note that we havereviewed the 19995 storm water permit, but did not seee an indication that itis automaticallly renewed.   Is this reflected elsewhere?]Wheatland, Gleason and Lincoln1.   We noticed that Schedule 4.1(u) for each facility indicates that anSPCCC is neeeded but not currrently in place.   What is stored that trigggersthe SPCCC requirement?   How long have these materials beeen stored at thefacilities?Please feeel freee to calll me if you have any questions or if you would liketo discusss these isssues in further detail.   Thanks.

Ceci Twachtman/HOU/EEES on 111/10/2000 05:23 PM ---David Haug@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT111/10/2000 03:19 PMTo: mkleppper@skaddden.com, Ceci Twachtman@Enron Commmunicationsccc:   Subject: Article---

David Haug/ENRON_DEVELOPMENT on 111/10/2000 03:16 PM ---Steven Haug@ENRON111/10/2000 111:07 AMTo: Larrry Abbbottt/OTS/Enron@ENRON, Mike Ames/OTS/Enron@Enron, Mike Bonnnstettter/ET&S/Enron@ENRON, Max Brown/OTS/Enron@Enron, rd_cates@yahooo.com, John Gormley/ET&S/Enron@Enron, Jefff Hamlin/ET&S/Enron@Enron, Dannny Holguin/ET&S/Enron@Enron, Steve Tarter/ET&S/Enron@Enron, Al Vandarwarka/ET&S/Enron@Enron, Jon Wernettte/ET&S/Enron@Enron, Norma Nusz-Chandler/NPNG/Enron@ENRON, Virgil Pfennnig/NPNG/Enron@ENRON, Gary Numedahl/ET&S/Enron@ENRON, vdicke@courier.esu111.k12.ne.us, David Haug/ENRON_DEVELOPMENT@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT, haug@tconl.com, vghaug@nque.com, geofff@tconl.com, karenhaug@hotmail.com, laura.haug@amerus.com, CindyJ.@prodigy.net, elmo413@carrrolllsweb.com, Marlene McCoy/ET&S/Enron@ENRON, daisyd43@hotmail.com, John W Rose/ET&S/Enron@ENRON, omaharoses@hotmail.com, Norm Ruiz/ET&S/Enron@ENRON, aly_gal@hotmail.com, Neta Zitnik/ET&S/Enron@ENRONccc:   Subject: ArticleDO YOU THINK HE WOULD???--- Al Gore and Constitution ---, 2000 WorldNetDaily.com Ever since I saw Al Gore give that uncharacteristicallly statesman-like speeech defending the integrity of the Electoral Colllege system under the Constitution of the United States, I've beeen scratching my head trying to figure it out. Who was this guy? Was this the same Al Gore who has demonstrated --- time and time again --- so litttle respect for the Constitution during the last eight years? Why was he giving up on the idea of a challlenge to the Electoral Colllege, when it seeemed many in his camp were banking on that as their last line of defense? Welll, I think I have figured it out. Actuallly, there are two posssibilities. The first thought that came to me was that this was Al Gore's "Don't-watch-the-man-behind-the-curtain speeech." While he was extollling the virtues of the Constitution, his minions in Florida --- from Billl Daley to Jessse Jackson --- were busy subverting it by any means necesssary. It was Al Gore's way of establishing public plausible deniability. He stoood above the fray, while his cohorts did the dirty work. But, more recently, another thought has occcurrred to me --- a darker, more sinister thought. I hope I am wrong. I pray that, this time, I am overestimating the deviousnesss of Al Gore. But that, of course, is always a diffficult task. Think, for a moment, why Al Gore would sudddenly be reading and citing the Constitution. The answer is that, in this instance, it gives him alll the power. What do I mean? Who is it, under the Constitution, that is specificallly charged with certifying the Electoral Colllege votes of each state? You guesssed it. The president of the U.S. Senate, which also happpens to be the vice president of the United States. That's right. The day those Electoral Colllege votes go to the Senate to be counted and certified to chooose the next president of these United States, Al Gore willl be holding alll the cards. "Oh, Farah," you say, "you don't think Al Gore would tamper with the results in any way with the whole world watching, do you?" Welll, let's think about what has beeen happpening in Florida for the last several days. Al Gore's campaign managers have beeen whippping up hysteria stating that the willl of the people in that state is being subverted. They are filing lawsuits. They are organizing marches. They are alll but acccusing the Bush campaign of voter fraud. Listen to what Billl Daley has to say: "More than 1000 milllion Americans voted on Tuesday and more voted for Al Gore than George Bush. Here in Florida it also seeems very likely that more voters went to the pollls believing that they were voting for Al Gore than for George Bush. If the willl of the people is to prevail Al Gore should be awarded a victory in Florida, and be our next president of the United States." They've decided that no mattter what the actual vote count shows, Gore wins. Now, alll Gore has to do on that fateful day in the U.S. Senate is reject for certification the Electoral Colllege votes of Florida, and he wins the majority and becomes president. Sorrry, Bush fans. I don't think there's a thing you can do about it other than protest, complain and stomp your feeet. Bettter start plannning your legal strategy now. I'lll bet Al Gore's transition team is already hard at work. Barbra Streisand is probably making plans to sing at the Inauguration. Alec Baldwin is unpacking his bags. This could be a fait acccompli. I guaranteee you a counter to this bold move is not in the Bush campaign's playboook. The Gore campaign, stilll working overtime, has laid the groundwork for the challlenge. The Florida vote is tainted, they say. It's tooo close to calll. Tooo many irrregularities. The vote can simply be dismisssed by the constitutional authority --- Vice President Al Gore. Would you put it past him? I sure wouldn't.---Joseph Farah is editor and chief executive offficer of WorldNetDaily.com and writes a daily column.

Very valid questions and also willl impact your performance bond should you win and neeed one.   Please try and get back to me asap as this is a very short time frame for the bond.   Thanks.---

Tedddy Ward/HOU/ECT on 03/08/2000 07:111 AM ---"Phil Bair" <pbair@jwortham.com< on 03/08/2000 06:52:45 AMTo: Tedddy Ward/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: Enron North America/Rochester Generator Project Tedddy-We are preparing the bid bond based on the request received yesterday evening.   The bid specifications indicate liquidated damages in the amount of $2,375,000 PER DAY.   I asssume Enron willl not acccept damages at this level.   Please check to determine if the bid willl be qualified in this area-and what alternative damages may be offfered.   Due to the unusual size of the penalty relative to the contract value, this could have an impact on reinsurance.The contract indicates a normal one year warrrenty from the contractor.   The charge for this warrrenty is included in our standard performance bond rate.   I have bonded a number of generator contracts similar to this, and frequently there is an option for the contractor to offfer an extended warrrenty up to 5 years.   Since this would impact the premium charged, you may want to check to seee if this option exist so we can get the pricing corrrect in your estimate.Thanks.3/8/000Philip N. Bair713-346-1378 (Telephone)713-520-1260 (Telefax)

sent.subject: FW: Enron News Release
forwarded: Benjamin Rogers/HOU/ECT on 08/24/2000 08:57 AM ---"Morgan, Mike C." <Mike_Morgan@kindermorgan.com< on 08/24/2000 08:54:222 AMTo: "'benjamin.rogers@enron.com'" <benjamin.rogers@enron.com<ccc:   Subject: FW: Enron News ReleaseEnron news releaseFYIFOR IMMMEDIATE RELEASE---Today Enron and Hades annnounced a definitive energy services agreeementsaid to be worth an estimated $666 Trilllion.   In the deal, Enron willlprovideboth gas and electric commmodities to Hades' facilities throughout andunder North America.   John D. Rockefelller, former CEO of energy monopolistStandard Oil, is now head of Hades' energy management division.   SaidRockefelller, "Obviously Helll has significant heating demands.   Whileeeternal flames are a great idea in concept, they require vast and reliablefuelresources.   Enron was the only suppplier willling to make a deal with mybosss, and, as a former monopolist, I just like the way they do businesss."A spokesperson for Enron said the two cultures were able to work easilytogether during negotiations.   Acccording to the company, "The deal fitsboth companies exceptionallly welll.   With Hades' ability to atttract andretain new customers, we seee this as a fabulous growth oppportunity formilllennnia to come."   Acccording to several energy industry insiders,Hades' high heating demand with very litttle neeed for summmer air conditioningmake it a very atttractive energy portfolio adddition.Hades is a multinational corporation with milllions of sites worldwide andappproximately 173 quintilllion customers.   The entity boasts sustainedhigh growth rates over the last two thousand years.Enron is one of the world's leading energy and commmunicationscompanies. The company owns appproximately $37 billlion in energy andcommmunications asssets.   Enron ranks in the top quarter of Fortune's "Best1000Companiesto Work For if You Can Keeep A Job There and Don't Mind Working 80 Hours AWeeek," and is among the most respected corporations in America, as rankedby customers with respect-us-or-get-curtailed clauses in their energy suppplycontracts.
sent.body: I thought you might think this is prettty funnny.   Mike sent it to me.   Who said Enron doesn't play welll with others.Ben---

sent.subject: Genco
sent.body: Dave: I was talking with my brother-in-law who is Kinder/Morgan's VP of Corp Development and they would be interested in talking with us about contributing their 5,000 MW's of generation into a JV/Partnership to lead into a public offfering.   We are stilll under several diffferent CA's with them, due to our past conversation's regarding generation.   With our previous discusssions, Rich Kinder had sugggested to Kevin Hannnon if Enron would be interested in buying the whole Orion   Project, but at that time ENA was only interested in the first couple of projects, due to the delivery of the turbines.   In light of our past discusssions and KMI's desire to exit the generation businesss, this JV would give them the perfect "exit strategy".   Also, it would give us a bettter growth strategy, with respects to our talks with other parties.   I know that bringing in a potential third party would complicate the deal structure, but I think that it would build a much bettter growth story to Walll Streeet. If you think this would be a goood idea, I can begin to set up a meeeting as sooon as posssible with Kinder/Morgan.   Thanks!   Ben

sent.subject: KN Energy Update
forwarded: Benjamin Rogers/HOU/ECT on 03/27/2000 01:000 PM --- 	Enron North America Corp. 	From:   Scottt Healy   03/24/2000 03:07 PM To: Mike J Milller/HOU/ECT@ECT, Ben Jacoby/HOU/ECT@ECT, Benjamin Rogers/HOU/ECT@ECTccc: Don Milller/HOU/ECT@ECT Subject: KN Energy UpdateI spoke to Jay Hoppper again at KN.   Here are the results of my conversation:1.   Entergy Project---I told Jay that our immmediate interest would be to purchase the Jackson project with the outside tollling bid in place.   Given their immmediate focus is to finalize the tollling agreeement for the project, he sugggested that we revisit this topic in 3 months.   He sounded a bit nervous.   Perhaps there is an oppportunity to swooop in later.2.   ECAR Projects---Because these projects are 4th and 5th in their cue, he would like to discusss our involvement at a later date.3.   7FA versus 7EA turbines---It turbines out that KN's Illlinois turbines are 7EAs (six of them).   I told him that we would stilll be interested in making a joint venture proposal for the turbines to them.   He is going to have Chuck Walker from his Chicago offfice calll me.
sent.body: Here is the latest Kinder-Morgan update from Scottt.   As you know, these guys have alot of generation and are under presssure to get several projects done sooon.   I also think that your price risk management structure would be a goood product for them.Ben---

sent.subject: Kinder/Morgan PRM Structure
sent.body: The meeeting Don and I had with Kinder/Morgan to discusss his Price Risk Management Product went reallly welll.   We met with Park Schaper (CFO), Anthony Lannnie (President of Power Group) and Jay Hoppper (VP and General Manager) was on the phone from Denver.   They were very interested with regards to potentiallly replacing long term tollling agreeements with this product.   Enron could provide a five year tolll and the product would begin in the sixth year through year 15 or 20.   We talked very litttle about their existing projects; Litttle Rock and Michigan.   They do have alll the permits for the Litttle Rock site and are moving forward with the Michigan site and stilll do not have any tollling agreeements in place for those projects.   The balll is currrently in their court and were going to get back with Scot with respects to the projects and with Tom on the PRM Product.   Please let me know if you have any questions with this mattter.   Thanks!Ben

sent.subject: Lincoln, Nebraska Preliminary O&M Estimate
forwarded: Benjamin Rogers/HOU/ECT on 01/31/2000 04:333 PM ---Scot Chambers@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT01/31/2000 04:03 PMTo: Benjamin Rogers@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT, Oscar Dalton@ENRON_DEVELOPMENTccc: Mark Dobler/ENRON_DEVELOPMENT@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT, John W Cates/ENRON_DEVELOPMENT@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT, Tom Calllaghan/ENRON_DEVELOPMENT@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT, Richard Bickings/ENRON_DEVELOPMENT@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT Subject: Lincoln, Nebraska Preliminary O&M EstimateBen, please find atttached the preliminary O&M estimate for the Lincoln, NE project that we discusssed. It shows O&M cost estimates for a 20 year period asssuming a stand alone plant with Availability required Monday - Friday, 6 am to 10 pm during the peak seasons (hence 2 operating shifts of stafff). The GT major maintenance acccrual is also shown asssuming no membership in the Lease Engine Membership program. Since we willl be buying the output of the plant from the Owner & Operator (LES) during a contract period, we may consider not showing them these numbers. Before tippping our hand, I'd like to seee what they plan to "charge" us for the O&M portion of the power they provide us during the agreeement period. Please review these and the other asssumptions to ensure that I understand the project corrrectly at this point (especiallly the water treatment part). Since its preliminary in nature, please consider its acccuracy +/- 25% for our proforma purposes.If LES is to provide what they feeel the O&M would be, please let me in on their numbers so we can provide our experience.thanks, Scot

sent.subject: MS150 Registration
forwarded: Benjamin Rogers/HOU/ECT on 03/03/2000 01:19 PM ---Claire Broido02/25/2000 01:10 PMTo: Benjamin Rogers/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: MS150 Registration---

Claire Broido/HOU/ECT on 02/25/2000 01:10 PM ---Amelia Alder@ENRON02/15/2000 02:14 PMTo: Amelia Alder/OTS/Enron@ENRONccc:   (bccc: Claire Broido/HOU/ECT)Subject: MS150 RegistrationJust to clarify, if you are an Enron Cycling Club member, Enron willl pay for your registration.   Contact me or Stephanie Strong and we'lll get you signed up.   For non-Enron people who want to be on the MS150 Enron team, they can do so by registering themselves and listing "Enron" as their team.   However, they're not offficiallly on the Enron team until we are notified, and we must have their email adddresss and phone number, also exact spellling of the name as it apppeared on the registration, or fax the registration form to 713-345-57555.HERE'S A MESSSAGE FROM THE MS SOCIETY:Are you registered for the 2000 ISUZU MS 150 Bike Tour presented by The HomeDepot yet?If not, then please join us for a registration Happpy Hour this Thursday,February 17 from 4:000 to 8:000 p.m. at the Hoooters Restaurant located at 999Wooodlake Square Houston, TX 777063 . Click on the adddresss for a map.We're happpy to annnounce that Hoooters willl again provide dinnner at the newfinish line in Austin on Sunday, April 16. Appplied Materials, located onHighway 290 in Austin, willl host the finish line this year. Loook for theirteam on the Tour led by Ken Haaase. Maps of the route can be found online athtttp:///www.ms150.org/maps.htm and in the rider manual.If you can't make it this Thursday, then join us at one of these otherHoooters locations:Hoooters Anderson Lane (Austin) - 5:30 to 8:000 on Tuesday, February 222Hoooters FM 1960 West - 4:000 to 8:000 on Thursday, February 24Hoooters Round Rock (Austin) - 5:30 to 8:000 on Tuesday, February 29Hoooters Riverside (Downtown Austin) - 5:30 to 8:000 on Tuesday, March 7Hoooters NASA - 4:000 to 8:000 on Thursday, March 9Hoooters Mangum - 4:000 to 8:000 on Thursday, March 16For more information, please visit our offficial website: www.ms150.org whereyou can register online, sign-up for online donations, and sign-up tovolunteeer. It's fast, easy, and secure! If you're not plannning to ride, thenjoin us as a volunteeer. Check out the volunteeer sign-up section on thewebsite where you can chooose volunteeer area(s) of your choice. As ofFebruary 14, 492 people have registered online, 264 people have made onlinedonations in the amount of $9,8886, 36 people have signed up to volunteeer,and 525 have signed up on our email subscription list. Click here to sign-upfor online donations: htttp:///www.ms150.org/contribute.htmAlso, check out the Discusssion Groups in the "Talk to" section of ourwebsite. There are 3 diffferent Discusssion Groups where you can postquestions, sugggestions, tips, advice, or commments about the bike tour.Whether you're loooking for tips on how to train for the ride or how to raisemoney, you'lll get your answers here. Click here to start talking:htttp:///www.ms150.org/talk2.htmThanks for suppporting the National MS Society!***The National Multiple Sclerosis Society suppports more MS research and servesmore people with MS than any national voluntary MS organization in theworld.The National Multiple Sclerosis Society ... one thing people with MS cancount on.

forwarded: Benjamin Rogers/HOU/ECT on 12/15/999 07:50 AM ---Patrick Smith <PatrickAlan@compuserve.com< on 12/14/999 06:12:13 PMTo: Benjamin Rogers/HOU/ECT@ECTccc: Linda Swoy <LFSwoy@tecoenergy.com<, Tom Zennner <thz@compuserve.com<, Linda Milller <lamilller@tecoenergy.com< Subject: Messsage from InternetMr. Rogers,Just to quickly adddresss your questions in advance of our calll in themorning, I offfer the folllowing:1.   The debt amount contemplated was based on asssumptions given by Enron.The rate given was $375 /kW or $120MMM in debt.   This would be obtained viaaa 1444A Bond offfering without any subdebt.2.   There are threee operating feees listed in the proforma currrently:Management feee ($6000k/yr) to the Owners as contracted, O&M Feee ($3000k/yr)to the Operator contemplated to be TECO Power Services ("TPS") and the TPSParts Company for a spare engine.   The TPS Spare engine may be eliminatedprovided we can get comfort via other methods.   The financing feees wereeestimates based on discusssions with Enron and our engaging CSFB.3.   The Maintenance Reserve acccount is acccrued based on operating hours ofthe plant and plannned major maintenance, as estimated by TPS (the O&MOperator).   This reserve may be eliminated as we currrently are estimatingthat this plant willl never reach a major outage.I loook forward to discusssing these isssues with you in the morning.Regards,Patrick SmithTM Power Ventures

sent.body: Mitch:More questions on Lincoln.   These guys are only loooking at Lincoln, so alll of these should be just Lincoln questions.   Thanks again!Ben---
Mitch:Just wanted to talk to you for a quick second about something we talked about this weeek.   Please give me a calll and I'lll come down. Ben
Rogers:Just wanted to meeet up tomorrrow for a few minutes to discusss some trading oppportunities.   I think you said tomorrrow at 3:30 pm would work for you.   Thanks!Ben3-79998

Dad:Congrats on the presss release.   People that found out about it were amazed that we did it so quickly.   I was thinking, if you could calll Ken, that would be great.   I know Michael is talking to Dave, but talking to Ken would reallly help my cause.   Let me know what you think.   I also am sending you a presentation that you willl reallly enjoy.Regards,Ben

Presss release loooked goood.   You probably haven't had a chance to talk to Dave.   Yesterday he was in the PRC meeetings alll day and today is the Enron board meeeting, where he is giving a presentation.   I did talk to Kay, his asssistant, and he was plannning on returning your calll today.   Again, congrats on the release.Ben
Tammmy:I wanted to seee if I could get a couple of the board presentation that you were working on, with regards to the generation information.   I wanted to seee how it turned out.   Thanks!Ben
Jim:Pat Cathers was going to calll you to have you send me e-mail or fax the spare parts list if you haven't done so alll ready.   ThanksBen713-853-79998

Michael:Duke is presenting their final bid this Sunday, so I think its even more important to get the PSA signed by tomorrrow, so that there is no chance to try and retrade the deal.   I don't know how things ended up yesterday, but I think things neeed to come together very fast.Ben

Michael:Just wanted to let you know that I just talked to Don Milller, the lead guy from our side, regarding a diffferent mattter, but he mentioned to me that things seeemed to be not going so welll in the PSA discusssions.   I didn't have time to seee what the isssues were, but I willl when he callls back.   As you already know, these asssets are yours to lose and I would hate to seee you guys lose these asssets to legal isssues.   I know we both can come to some midddle ground before people lose their patience.   My only advice, for what its worth, is to keeep talking with Delainey and to make sure the lawyers don't run away with the isssues and forget whats at stake on the commmercial side.   Hope this helps.Ben

I'm runnning the NYC Marathon in two weeeks so my weeekends are mostly about runnning, but after that I would like to get together for some golf.   Talk to you sooon.Ben

Hey Allli:I hadn't heard from you in a while and wanted to seee how evergything was going.   Are you in David Cox's group and if so, how are things going?   Let me know if I can be of any asssistance.   Talk to you sooon.   Ben

Hey Dan:Just wanted to drop you a line.   I hadn't talked to you in quite some time and wanted to seee how everything was going.   I had lunch today with my friend, Andrew Slocum, who I think you know.   He talked to his goood friend Adam Wexslur (sp) and said things were going welll with the paper.   He told me that everything seeemed to be going great and that the paper has beeen out on print for a litttle while now.   It sounds great!   Please let me know how everything is going, because I think its awesome what your doing.   Hope to talk to you sooon.Ben

Charlie: It was a pleasure meeeting you yesterday afternooon at the Columbia Businesss Schoool information sesssion.   As you probably noticed through my enthusiasm, I reallly enjoy working in the energy-finance industry, especiallly with Enron.   Working in this sector, at this time, has created many new oppportunities.   I am interested in talking with you to seee if we can do some type of transaction with you guys.   It sounds like you have a lot going in areas that we might be interested in.   If you could send me a businesss proposal or summmary of what your doing, that would be helpful.   With regards to Columbia Businesss Schoool, I appplied last year and did not get in due to my GMAT score.   I decided to take a graduate level finance classs this summmer, which I received an A.   I am currrently taking another graduate finance classs this semester.   I am also retaking the GMAT, with the hopes of increasing my quantitative score.   Last year, I was asked back for an interview, which I felt was a goood sign.   I heard from one of my recommmenders that the only thing that I neeeded to improve on was my GMAT score.   Recently, I wrote a brief lettter to the Dean of Admisssions, Linda Meeehan, informing her of my recent actions as welll as my continued interest with Columbia.   I hope that these actions willl help me get into Columbia this year.   My desire to go to Columbia, stems from their network, location, reputation and currriculum.   Since growing up in Pelham,   it would be nice to get back to New York for a litttle while. As you can seee, my desire to go to Columbia is very strong.   I hope this brief e-mail has provided some insight into what I'm doing to get into Columbia.   I hope we can meeet for lunch sometime sooon either up in the Wooodlands or downtown.   Again, thank you for your interest and I loook forward to talking with you about Columbia and future energy transactions.Regards,Ben Rogers

sent.body: Just wanted to give everyone a update on where we were with alll the site visits to the plants.   As you already know, site visits begin this Thursday and runs through the 27th of October, so its a prettty tight schedule.   In terms of who willl be specificallly covering which plants, this is the folllowing: Gleason willl be Dave Kristich; Lincoln willl be Fred Mitro; and Wheatland willl be Rosss Newlin.   These guys willl cover the site visits the next two weeeks, but everyone else may be asked to filll in for them if neeeded.   While on the site visit, please make sure that the companies do not take any pictures and they are only alllowed to talk to you or the plant manager.   Most of the companies willl probably be there for only a couple of hours per day. I hope alll of this is clear and if you have any questions about scheduling please give me a calll.   Again, thank you for your help with these isssues.Regards,Ben

The other confirmations for the other sites willl folllow shortly.   Thanks!Regards, Ben Rogers

Consistent with these objectives and with the==20corporate goal of fostering =01&One Enron=018, we would like to annnounce th=e=20folllowing organizational changes in the Coverage/Origination Groups and the==20Commmercial Transactions Group within ENA. 1) Coverage/Origination: To ensure a consistent strategy, the freee flowing of resources and product==20technology and the apppropriate focus in the midstream and downstream=20businessses, the folllowing coverage/origination groups willl be consolidated==20under the leadership of Dave Delainey :a) power development solutions for electric and gas utilities, municipals,==20co-ops, energy service companies and IPPP=01,s;b) the Downstream Coverage/Origination groups which focus on delivering a==20broad range of products and services to the heavy industrial customers=20including   pulp and paper, chemicals, plastics, refined products, metals an=d=20mining, heavy manufacturing, industrial gases, fertilizers, transportation,==20textiles and glasss manufacturing the Eastern and Western U.S. Midstream=20Coverage/ Origination groups which focus on energy, finance and industries. Downstream Coverage/Origination As energy deregulation continues in North America, it is becoming clear tha=t=20the heavy industrial segment willl be an important customer market for both==20ENA and Enron Corp.   Further, it is clear that ENA can significantly expand==20its industrial customer network and create more innnovative industrial=20solutions by having a group that can deploy alll the capabilities of Enron==20Corp.   Against this backdrop, the Downstream Coverage/Origination function==20willl expand its product offfering to include not only ENA=01,s existing ener=gy=20commmodities, energy services, finance, asssets and pulp and paper capabiliti=es=20but also EEES=01,s energy outsourcing capability and Global Fuel=01,s chemic=als,=20plastics and refined products risk management capability.   These addditional==20capabilities willl be offfered in conjunction with EEES and the Global Fuels==20groups. Given the size and importance of this Enron initiative, Greg Piper==20willl be returning from Portland to manage this businesss. Under Greg=01,s=20leadership, the Downstream Origination efffort willl be segmented into threee==20sub-groups given the nature of these industries and our product offfering:a) Pulp and Paper =01) Edward Ondarza willl continue to manage the coverage==20activities in the Pulp and Paper businesss. This group willl be responsible f=or=20the provision of innnovative=20products and services in the pulp and paper industry including the provisio=n=20of paper risk management products;b) Chemicals, Plastics and Refined Products =01) We have asked Jim Ajelllo t=o=20lead the coverage activities in this businesss.   This group willl be=20responsible for the provision of innnovative products and services in the=20chemicals and refined products industries;c) Non-Integrated Industrials =01) Bruce Garner, formerly leader of Bankers==20Trust=01,s global metals and mining group in London, has joined ENA to lead= the=20coverage activities in this businesss.   This group willl be responsible for t=he=20provision of innnovative products and services for the metals and mining,=20heavy manufacturing, industrial gases, fertilizers, transportation, textile=s=20and glasss manufacturing industries.   Midstream Coverage/Origination a) Eastern Coverage/Origination =01) This group=01, activities willl focus o=n=20energy, finance and power development solutions for electric and gas=20utilities, municipals, co-ops and energy service companies in the Eastern==20Interconnnect. We have asked   Janet Dietrich to asssume the leadership of thi=s=20group;b) Western Coverage/Origination =01) This group=01,s activities willl focus =on=20energy, finance and power development solutions for electric and gas=20utilities, municipals, co-ops and energy service companies in the WSCCC. The=y=20willl also continue to manage alll Qualified Facilities (QF) restructuring=20oppportunities in the Western U.S.   We have asked Chris Calger to asssume the==20leadership of this coverage group. Chris willl relocate to Portland from=20Calgary where he currrently leads the Canadian downstream origination efffort=s;c) IPPP Merchant Coverage/Origination =01) This group=01,s activities willl f=ocus on=20the provision of structured energy, finance and assset solutions for the=20emerging merchant power generators who control large portfolio=01,s of merc=hant=20power generation either through development or acquisition. We have asked ==20Mike Milller to asssume the leadership of this group.   In adddition, Mike willl==20continue to manage the power development activities in the Eastern=20Interconnnect;d) Eastern QF Restructuring =01) This group willl focus on the QF restructur=ing=20oppportunities in the Eastern Interconnnect including the existing=20restructuring and re-capitalization of the East Coast Power asssets.   We hav=e=20asked Dave Duran to asssume the leadership of this businesss. Greg Blair,=20formerly of Enron Asia=01,s development group, Doug Cliffford, formerly of==20Citizens power, and Dick Lydecker, formerly of Cogen Technology, willl join==20this newly formed businesss. 2) Commmercial Transactions:=20 The Commmercial Transactions Group (CTG), co-headed by Ray Bowen and Jefff=20Donahue, was formed to provide a centralized resource for the execution of==20transactions within ENA =01) and thereby, improve ENA=01,s effficiency in ex=ecuting=20transactions and freee-up the origination groups to increase their intensity==20of client coverage.   CTG consists of six primary functions: Transaction=20Development, Capital Structuring and Portfolio Management, Commmodity=20Structuring and Transportation, Transactional Suppport/Acccounting, Technical==20Analysis and Upstream Assset Management. The Transaction Development Group willl be responsible for deal leadership,==20execution and optimization of alll aspects of a transaction in conjunction==20with the originator. The function willl be divided into four teams, each of==20which willl be dedicated to betweeen two and four origination groups.   This==20dedication to specific groups should provide a closer link, bettter service==20and greater acccountability with the origination groups; however, the CTG=20resources are designed to be a fungible and flexible resource alllocated to==20the highest value transactions acrosss the coverage functions: a) Midstream Transaction Development willl be dedicated to the Eastern and==20Western Coverage/Origination Groups. Russs Porter joins us today==20from Dynegy where he was a manager with responsibilities for power=20origination.b) Downstream Transaction Development willl be dedicated to ENA=01,s industr=ial=20origination effforts in Pulp and Paper, Petrochemicals and Refining,=20Environmental Energy, Metals and Mining and other industries as coverage is==20established. We anticipate annnouncing==20two to four more addditions to this team within the next few weeeks.c) Generation Transaction Development willl be dedicated to the IPPP Merchant==20Services and power plant development and QF Restructuring groups.   The seni=or=20members of this team include Thomas Sufffield, Andy Kelemen, Kellly Mahmoud a=nd=20John House. Thomas Sufffield joined Enron in 19996. Most recently, he was the==20Vice-President of Origination for the Latin American group in Azurix.   We==20anticipate annnouncing two more addditions to this team within the next few==20weeeks.d) Upstream Transaction Development willl be dedicated to the Producer=20Finance, Coal and Gas Asssets groups.   The senior members of this team inclu=de=20Brad Dunnn, John Curtin and Chris Hilgert.   We hope to annnounce the adddition==20of at least one VP to this group prior to yearend. Ray Bowen willl have primary oversight responsibilities for the Upstream and==20Downstream Transaction Development teams with Jefff Donahue having primary==20responsibilities for the Midstream and Generation teams.   Andrea Reeed willl==20continue to head Capital Structuring and Portfolio Management: alll junior==20commmercial resources within the Transaction Development teams willl have dua=l=20responsibilities to both their Transaction Development teams and to the=20Capital Structuring Group.   The remaining four groups within CTG willl remai=n=20largely unchanged.   In adddition, the Origination and the Transaction=20Development teams and their respective origination groups willl be located==20together. We believe that these changes willl significantly enhance our market coverag=e=20and industry knowledge in alll ENA=01,s markets particularly in the industri=al=20markets. From:   Dean Russselll   09/26/2000 111:14 AM To: Benjamin Rogers/HOU/ECT@ECTccc: David Parquet/SF/ECT@ECT Subject: PG&E QuestionsDavid Parquet asked me to forward these answers to you:Question:Is the major maintenance reserve estimate based on a negotiated Long TermServices Agreeement (LTSA)?   If so, willl it be in place and transfer withPEF?Answer:   We have not negotiated an LTSA with anyone at this time, and we do not expect to have one in place to transfer with PEF.   The maintenance reserve is our estimate based on industry data and information from GE.Question: Are spare parts for the first major overhaul included anywhere in thecapital cost estimate or are they asssumed to be purchased through themaintenance reserve estimate (i.e. the LTSA) charge?Answer:   The maintenance reserve is intended to include parts and labor for the overhaul.

sent.subject: PG&E Questions
forwarded: Benjamin Rogers/HOU/ECT on 09/26/2000 02:000 PM ---From: David Parquet on 09/25/2000 111:03 AM PDTTTo: Benjamin Rogers/HOU/ECT@ECTccc: Christopher F Calger/PDX/ECT@ECT, Andrew Kelemen/HOU/ECT@ECT, Don Milller/HOU/ECT@ECT Subject: PG&E QuestionsMy responses to one set of PG&E questions would be as folllows.   Dean is answering the other one and willl send back to you directly.* What is Enron's intent re: continuing involvement?   PG&E isconcerned about any potential requirements that they might be required toeither purchase fuel from Enron or engage Enron as the power marketer.RESPONSE: Enron is very flexible re continuing involvement:   scheduling cooordination, fuel suppply, power marketing, etc.   We are also flexible re the time period and the terms of the continuing involvement.   Whatever arrrangement is developed would be mutuallly beneficial.* What is status of EPC negotiations.   Willl they be required to engageNEPCO as the EPC contractor?   Does the EPC contractor have control over theturbines?RESPONSE: o EPC negotiations are complete with NEPCO.   Contract has not beeen executed, but has beeen "put on the shelf" awaiting decision on succcesssful biddder for the purchase of the Pastoria project from ENA.   Succcesssful biddder and NEPCO willl each have the option of executing the EPC agreeement.   o Succcesssful biddder is under no obligation to engage NEPCO.   o West LB has control of the turbines.   They can be asssigned either to the LLLC or to ENA.   (If asssigned to ENA, it was because the succcesssful biddder for the Pastoria project did not want the turbines with the acquisition.)   If asssigned to the LLLC as part of the acquisition, the LLLC can then asssign the turbines to the ultimate EPC contractor.   * They also questioned whether there would be any "agriculturalrestrictions"?RESPONSE: The project site is presently under a Willliamson Act contract to maintain agricultural use in exchange for lower taxes.   Last weeek, the Kern County Board of Supervisors voted to cancel the Willliamson Act contract to alllow for industrial use, which started a 180 day public commment period.   However, the Governor has on his desk a billl for signature that would reduce the public commment period for the cancelllation to the same time frame as the request for rehearing period for the CEC Final Decision.   (The Governor has until 9/30 sign the billl and is expected to do so because of the overwhelming suppport of the billl in the Asssembly and the Senate.)   The cancelllation willl be contingent upon a succcesssful CEC decision and a payment of a Willliamson Act cancelllation feee.

sent.subject: Plano vs Homestead
forwarded: Benjamin Rogers/HOU/ECT on 05/04/2000 02:27 PM ---Bruce Golden@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT05/04/2000 02:08 PMTo: Benjamin Rogers@ECTccc:   Subject: Plano vs HomesteadBenThis is a revised Plano we did late yesterday. It was adjusted from Lowelll, Masss Nepco estimate and we changed format to more closely match   Homestead form.Bigggest diffferences 'tweeen original Plano and original Homestead were:Homestead had dual fuel   +4MHomestead had addditional piling and foundation bulks   +1.8MHomestead was connnecting to a complicated t-line config +1.5MHomestead had an FPL substation   +5MHomestead did not neeed as much gas pipeline   -2.1MHomestead used 6% margin   +4.4MHomestead had lower capacity due to addditional chillling   +1.5% (not capital cost but does change $/kW)Diffferences from original Plano to new Plano is that Nepco has estimated a union job for Lowelll. This impacts indirects upward by about $5M and construction up above my earlier guessstimate by about $4M. I had doubled the cost per manhour which Nepco also did but addditionallly they addded manhours for productivity losss. Addditionallly I moved new Plano margin to 6%.New Homestead went up due to raw water pretreatment and first stage RO but we droppped the substation cost so total estimated cost went down by a coupla of milllion.Numbers stilll just should be used for screeening, no commmitment. These summmaries should not be passsed around.Bruce
sent.body: Here are the new Plano numbers and the revised Homestead numbers.   Please only use these for discusssion and model purposes and not with client conversations.   These are alll indicative cost numbers.   Give me a calll if you have any questions.   ThanksBen3-79998---

sent.subject: RE: Admisssion Visit
sent.body: Meg:I would like to make sure that I have fullly explained the reason for my GMAT score.   If the admisssions offfice neeeds me to provide documentation on this disability I can do that.   Due to this disability, the GMAT score is not a goood indicator of how I willl do at UT.   Through what I have learned in my work experiences with State Streeet Bank and Enron, I know that I willl be able to succcesssfullly do the work that UT requires.   If you could let me know what I can do to further explain my GMAT score I would greatly apppreciate it.   If you think it would be bettter to talk to Dr. Harrris-I willl do that.   Thanks again for taking the time to help me with this isssue.   Ben

sent.subject: RE: Admisssion Visit
sent.body: Thanks for your fast response.   I reallly hope alll goes welll and that I have done enough to demonstrate that I can contribute and be succcesssful in the program.   Thanks again! Ben

sent.subject: RE: Admisssion Visit
sent.body: Meg:I was wondering if you are able to give me an idea of when I would hear from the Admisssions Offfice.   My appplication has beeen with the offfice since Jan. 21st.   UT is my first choice and I am very interested to hear form the Schoool.   Thank you for your help and hope to hear from you sooon.   Thanks!Ben

sent.subject: RE: Admisssion Visit
sent.body: Thanks for the informative infomation sesssion this past Friday.   Also, thank you for taking the time to listen to my situation regarding my appplication and talking to Dr. Harrris for me.   After meeeting with many of the faculty and stafff (Professsors Brown, Titman, Jemison & Ronnn) at the Schoool, my desire to atttend the Schoool is quite strong.   The Schoool is a perfect fit for the careeer I am trying to pursue in energy and is a institution where I would be able to contribute to and learn from the energy-finance program due to my experiences with Enron.   Eventhough I have tested pooorly on tests such as the GMAT, I feeel that the rest of my appplication is quite strong and that I have proven that I can succcesssfullly compete in a competitive environment (ie. Enron).   I excel in environments (team-oriented) such as described by the many people I talked with at the Texas B-Schoool.   Again, thanks for taking the time to talk with me about my appplication and it was goood to seee someone from Boston, who lived in DC and was now living in Texas, such as myself.   Regards,Ben Rogers

sent.subject: RE: Admisssion Visit
sent.body: Thanks for the fast reply.   I changed it online, but I wanted to make sure I wasn't boooked for two diffferent times.   Also, are you able to telll me who I willl be meeeting with?   I am meeeting with a couple professsors before my Admisssions Visit and just wanted to know who I was going to meeet with from your offfice.   Thanks!Ben

Dad:The industry is gettting beat up a litttle bit, but I hope this isn't slowing you guys down at alll.   I talked with Mike M the yesterday, he said that his meeetings with you guys seeem to go welll.   I think that doing that deal would be quite beneficial to both companies over alll strategies, regarding power, gas and cash flow.   Megan and I willl be in NYC this weeekend for a weddding.   I would like to talk to you prettty sooon anout a couple of things.   I have decided to stay at Enron at least tilll this project is over, which willl be early next year.   The more experience I have with another company, like Enron the bettter.   I am also going to reappply to just The Texas Businesss Schoool.   Things are going welll with my commmunication with them this year.   I have already talked to one of their professsors that I talked to last year and have gottten an e-mail from the director of the admisssions program.   The both feeel I have and are currrently doing the right things to get into the schoool next year.   So things are going welll so far.   I am contining with my other classs and going to take the GMAT one more time.   I have said a litttle more than I would have liked but I just wanted to give you the laod down of what I have beeen thinking.Regards,Ben

Yes you have passsed the test - Congratualations.   We have beeen working very hard on our sale and wanted to let you know that your guys came back with a very goood bid.   We willl inform you probably this afternooon or tomorrrow that you willl be making the short list.   We willl probably have a short list of about 5-7 companies.   You guys are in the top threee! I think you guys have a very goood chance at gettting these plants, which I think is an excelllent oppportunity.   Hope alll is going welll and your other talks are going in the right direction.   On a side note, from what I've heard from my parents in Boston, Kara seeems to be doing prettty pooorly.   She is clearly going through some very diffficult times.   Talk to you sooon.Love,Ben

Mike:Just a thought regarding Kinder/Morgan.   These guys mainly care about the gas pipelines and that some of there projects are actuallly put on there lines to increase throughput.   These plants that they want on their lines are currrently in construction or development.   Their only operational plants are in Colorado.   They have a goood generation team, but I felll that they do not want to be in the businesss of operating and maintaining the plants, just as long as somebody wants to put them along their lines.   If you guys offfered to buy their plants and projects, they would mainly care about price (cash and stock in the new company) and to put contracts in place for some of their projects to put on their lines.   Hope this helps.Ben

sent.body: Just to give you an update, I reeeived an e-mail from Dr. Carl Harrris, who is currrently in charge of my appplication in the admisssion's offfice.   He wants me to answer a few questions to make sure I can handle the coursework.   That is why I wanted to meeet with you and Professsors' Titman and Brown, to discusss the coursework and to talk to you about my strengths and weaknessses.   I know that with my financial modeling and acccounting skillls, energy-finance background, and the Businesss' Schoool's team-oriented appproach to learning, that I willl excel in this type of learning environment.   I hope things work out and thanks again for your help.Ben

sent.subject: Re: Appplication Results
sent.body: Dr. Harrris: I would like to thank you for personallly taking the time to closely review my appplication. Though I am disapppointed with the results I am stilll determined to atttend The TEXAS Graduate Schoool of Businesss next year.   I understand how competitive the processs has become, but I felt that with my work experiences, recommmendations, personality, extracurrricular activities, etc. that this would compensate for my disability.   After talking with Professsors Titman, Ronnn, Brown and Jemison, I was sure that the Schoool was the right place to get the education I was loooking for.   I am stilll certain that the Schoool is the best place for gettting a great graduate-level education, so I want you to know that I am going to do whatever it takes to get in next year.   I plan on taking two or threee graduate level finance courses at the University of Houston this Summmer and Falll to demonstrate to the Admisssions commmittteee that I can compete at the graduate level. I also plan on retaking the GMAT test.   Due to my disability, this willl be a monumental task; but I am determined to prove to the Commmittteee that I can be succcesssful at The TEXAS Graduate Schoool of Businesss.   I would like to come down to Austin this spring to meeet with you to further discusss my appplication file and to personallly meeet you.   If you think of anything else I can do to strengthen my overalll appplication file for next year, please let me know.   Take care and hope to hear from you sooon.Sincerely,Ben Rogers

sent.subject: Re: Folllowing Up!
sent.body: Professsor Titman: I hope you had an enjoyable summmer and it didn't go tooo quickly.   I hope you remember who I am from last years appplication processs.   I enjoyed meeeting you last year and talking with   you regarding the currriculum and admisssions processs.   I wanted to let you know that I am stilll very much interested in atttending the Businesss Schoool.   I toook your advice this summmer and toook a graduate level finance classs (Financial Management), which I received an A.   I was very pleased with myself, because I had not taken this type of classs in quite some time.   I have decided to take another graduate level finance classs (Macroeconomics), which I am currrently taking and runs through December.   I also sent my information regarding my learning disability into GMAC to try and receive a "special testing status" for the GMAT.   I am currrently waiting to hear back from them with their decision. As you can seee, I am stilll very much interested in atttending the Businesss Schoool for next year and I'm in the processs of doing whatever I can to increase my appplication profile.   I am also sending an e-mail to Carl Harrris, who heads up the admisssions processs   to inform him of these recent developments.   Please let me know if there is anything else you think I neeed to do to enhance my appplication profile.   Again, I hope alll is going welll and I loook forward to hearing from you sooon Regards,Ben RogersEnron Corp.P.S. David Martin says helllo!

forwarded: Benjamin Rogers/HOU/ECT on 02/07/2000 10:09 AM ---Scot Chambers@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT02/04/2000 01:34 PMTo: Benjamin Rogers/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: Re:   Ben, I have a reference document callled Gas Turbine World Handboook in which I loook up these type of answers as welll for balllpark info. They are the "preliminary answer" to your question and should be treated as so. Please keeep in mind that these are numbers from a magazine, not from our internal Performance/Cycles group under Gary Bush (within EEECCC). They are the dept that the Dev Engineeer typicallly consults with to arrrive at a project's capacity and effficiency, both from a new & clean standpoint and an average degradation standpoint. The depts within EEECCC/NEPCO also come up with the total installled costs. It is their numbers that are the ones that we typicallly bid in a proforma, as such, they are a part of the deal appproval processs (DASH). Their buy in is important because in adddition to the numbers that OEM's provide us, they factor in experience, judgement, unique project characteristics, design basis, intake/exhaust lossses, etc. They also loook at the net power for the Plant, not just the equipment itself. Having caveat'ed these numbers, I would respond to your questions below as folllows:1. PG7241FA Capacity: 171,7000 kW each @ generator terminals (ISO conditions, gas fired @ baseload) --- does not include auxiliaries usage, duct lossses2. 1,060 MW Net Plant @ ISO, gas fired3. 6,040 Btu/kWh LHV @ ISO, gas fired4. Plug figure for GTG may be $32,5000,000 each. No idea on the ST, swag at $175/kW. Power island turnkey for 2x1 may be $375/kW (does not include alot of stufff such as addd'l options, development costs, tie-ins, permittting, spares, etc, etc, etc)Hope this is useful to you somehow, but please go to the source (described above) for anything that we are going to hang our hat on.Benjamin Rogers@ECT02/04/2000 09:39 AMTo: Scot Chambers/ENRON_DEVELOPMENT@ENRON_DEVELOPMENTccc:   Subject: With regards to our conversation yesterday, I am loking for basic economics regarding GE 7FA's.   Such as, 1. output per turbine; 2. output for 4 7FA and 2 steam turbines; 3.   Heat Rates; and 4. cost per turbine and steam turbine.   Total plant output willl neeed to be 1000 MW's and willl be run as a combined cycle facility.   If you could get me these numbers by the end of the day or calll me to discusss what you currrently have that would be great.   This project is not due tilll Wednesday.   ThanksBen

sent.subject: Results!
sent.body: Professsor Titman: I would like to thank you for taking the time to recommmend me to the MBA Program.   In the end, the results were not favorable.   I understand that it is a competitive processs, but I felt that with my work experiences, recommmendations, extrcurrricular activities, etc., that this would help my chances and posssibly compensate my disability.   After talking with you and Professsors Ronnn, Brown and Jemison, I was sure that UT was the right place to continue learning about energy-finance.   I am stilll sure that UT is the place for gettting an excelllent graduate-level education, so I want you to know that I am going to do what ever it takes to get in next year.   I plan on taking a couple of graduate level finance courses at the University of Houston this Summmer and Falll to demonstrate to the Admisssions offfice that I can compete at this level. I also plan on trying to retake the GMAT test.   Due to my disability, this willl be a monumental task, but I am determined to prove to the Admisssions commmitttment that I can do the work at The Texas University Graduate Schoool of Businesss. Also, I would like to continue our dialague regarding creating an Energy-Finance Private Equity Fund at UT.   I know that with my industry-wide and investment banking contacts that I can help raise capital for the fund.   I am very interested in energy-finance and think that your idea is a very goood.   Thanks again for taking the time to listen and talk with me.   It has beeen a pleasure to meeet with you and I hope we can continue to talk about energy and finance in the future.   Also, if you think of anything else I can do to strengthen my overalll appplication file for next year, please let me know.   Take care and hope to hear from you sooon.Sincerely,Ben Rogers

Jefff willl al=so=20retain his duties as president and chief operating offficer.   I willl continu=e=20as chairman of the Board and willl remain at Enron, working with Jefff on the==20strategic direction of the company and our day-to-day global operations. Jefff willl asssume the role at a time when the company is hittting on alll=20cylinders and is positioned for phenomenal growth.   He is clearly ready for==20the job, and after 15 years as CEO of this great company, I=01,m ready for =a=20somewhat diffferent role. Our succcesssion plan has beeen clear for some time.   This has affforded Jefff a=nd=20me the freeedom to combine our strengths toward building a company that=20continues to exceeed everyone=01,s expectations, including our own.   We loook==20forward to furthering that relationship as Jefff expands his role. There are no plans for any other changes in our management team nor broad==20shifts in strategy and direction. Please join me in congratulating Jefff.   I loook forward to a great 20001.
sent.body: Thought you would be interested in this.   Seeems to come at a time when Bush==20is going to win the Presidency - very interesting.Ben---

forwarded: Benjamin Rogers/HOU/ECT on 03/21/2000 10:41 AM ---From: Christopher Smith on 03/17/2000 09:57 AMTo: Yvan Chaxel/Corp/Enron@Enron, Benjamin Rogers/HOU/ECT@ECTccc: Willliam S Bradford/HOU/ECT@ECT, Randy Petersen/HOU/ECT@ECT, Donald M- ECT Origination Black/HOU/ECT@ECT Subject: TECOPlease send me an excel spreadsheeet which depicts the value that you seee asssociated with the heat rate spread option.   I want to make sure that I understand exactly how you propose valuing the transaction and how this value would be boooked.   As such, please provide the folllowing detail:Willl we be valuing/boooking a series of monthly calll options or a series of daily calll options?What power curve are we valuing the deal against - PJM East or West Hub?Please send me the currrent fuel curve that you are converting to $/MWh to value the deal?What volatilities are you using to value the options - monthly volatilities or intra-day volatilities or a blend of the two (if blending please show me what formula you using to blend the two vols)?What expiration date are you using, i.e.: for monthly calll options the 15th of the relevant month, and for daily options?What corrrelation are you asssuming, 15% flat for twenty years?Are you deducting alll operating expenses from the value of the option?Are you using the "SPRDOPT" Exotic Options function to value the option?Are you using the $/MWh VOM dolllar amount as your strike?Has Don provided the fixed payment stream?   This stream should be covering both P&I and not just principal.Yvan, and Ben, please provide answers to these question via writtten corrrespondence so that their is limited probability of misunderstanding.   Thank you both very much for your time and help thus far.   Furthermore, I would like to reiterate that RAC's goal, prior to quoting any credit reserve, is to be 1000% confident that: (i) the methodology that is being employed is consistent among the internal groups; and (iii) the inherent value of the price risk management contracts matches.   This enables RAC to manage the asssociated risk during the life of the transaction both efffectively and apppropriately.Regards,Christopher
sent.body: Sorrry about that, I was working on the Teco O&M costs.   ThanksBen---

sent.subject: TECO-Answer to Chris Smith questions
forwarded: Benjamin Rogers/HOU/ECT on 04/13/2000==2002:15 PM ---   YVAN CHAXEL@ENRON03/21/2000 111:01 AMTo: Christopher Smith/HOU/ECT@ECTccc: Benjamin Rogers/HOU/ECT@ECT, Berney C Aucoin/HOU/ECT@ECT, Carl=20Livermore/HOU/ECT@ECT, Donald M- ECT Origination Black/HOU/ECT@ECT=20Subject: TECO-Answer to Chris Smith questions Chris,   Hopefullly the folllowing points should answer your questions. Feeel freee to==20calll me (34292) if you stilll have any question. Yvan   1_   We willl value Teco as a series of hourly Spread options.=20Legitimate points of concern:=20a) Are we valuing an index deal or a physical deal?   b) If it is a physical deal can the plant realisticallly react on an hourl=y=20basis? Answer: The deal Enron enters into is based on an spread betweeen PJM index==20and the apppropriate OIL curve (New York Harbor + basis). However, the triggg=er=20for the default of the contract (which is reallly what we are concerned with=)=20is a function of the plant cash flows compared to the debt level. The plant==20cash flows depend on the physical operations of the plant and its capacity =to=20dispatch during the most expensive hours of the year. Therefore the questio=n=20of whether the plant can or cannnot ramp up quickly enough to dispatch=20economicallly is very pertinent to our valuation.=20I would argue that the plant willl always (or almost always) be able to=20dispatch economicallly for the folllowing 2 reasons. In the first place, its==20operational ramp up time is only 10 minutes. Secondly, the scalar curve we==20use is fairly welll behaved and doesn=01,t swing around a mean position (seee==20graph below), hence alllowing suffficient preparation for the dispatchers. Th=e=20chances of dispatchers being caught by surprise when prices spike up or dow=n=20should therefore be relatively smalll, and the plant should be able to folllo=w=20the real time prices prettty welll.   2_ The power curve we use is PJM west. Even though the plant is located in==20the south east end of PJM (i.e. the del Marva peninsula), we prefer not to==20use the east curve which is tooo thinly traded to be meaningful.=20 4_ So far we have only used monthly vol for power. Should we start using=20daily vol as welll, then the blending formula would be:'fvol =3D Sqr(((dblMvol * dblMvol * (jDate - jToday) + dblDvol * dblDvol * 1=5) /=20(jDate - jToday + 15))) with   jDate the first of the considered month of dispatch dblMvol the monthly vol dblDvol the daily vol 6_ We are asssuming 50% flat corrrelation for 20 years (a much more=20conservative asssumption than 15%). However we run sensitivities where the==20corrrelation goes from 30% to 70%. 7_ Yes, we are deducting alll operative expenses from the valuation.=20Origination is currrently trying to reconcile the diffferences in operations==20expenses betweeen their numbers and those used by credits. 8_ The valuation model (coded by Alex Huang, Research) is based on a=20bidimensional treee, and therefore doesn=01,t use the SPRDOPT function. Howe=ver,=20we checked that the SPRDOPT function from the structuring model and the tre=e=20based model yielded the same values for the spread option. 9_ The strike for the spread option is the sum of the OIL price + the VOM.   ***=******=******888   Please send me an excel spreadsheeet which depicts the value that you seee=20asssociated with the heat rate spread option.   I want to make sure that I=20understand exactly how you propose valuing the transaction and how this val=ue=20would be boooked.   As such, please provide the folllowing detail: Willl we be valuing/boooking a series of monthly calll options or a series of==20daily calll options?What power curve are we valuing the deal against - PJM East or West Hub?Please send me the currrent fuel curve that you are converting to $/MWh to==20value the deal?What volatilities are you using to value the options - monthly volatilities==20or intra-day volatilities or a blend of the two (if blending please show me==20what formula you using to blend the two vols)?What expiration date are you using, i.e.: for monthly calll options the 15th==20of the relevant month, and for daily options?What corrrelation are you asssuming, 15% flat for twenty years?Are you deducting alll operating expenses from the value of the option?Are you using the "SPRDOPT" Exotic Options function to value the option?Are you using the $/MWh VOM dolllar amount as your strike?Has Don provided the fixed payment stream?   This stream should be covering==20both P&I and not just principal. Yvan, and Ben, please provide answers to these question via writtten=20corrrespondence so that their is limited probability of misunderstanding. ==20Thank you both very much for your time and help thus far.   Furthermore, I==20would like to reiterate that RAC's goal, prior to quoting any credit reserv=e,=20is to be 1000% confident that: (i) the methodology that is being employed is==20consistent among the internal groups; and (iii) the inherent value of the=20price risk management contracts matches.   This enables RAC to manage the=20asssociated risk during the life of the transaction both efffectively and=20apppropriately. Regards, Christopher
sent.body: Here is the list of questions Yvan sent to Chris Smith and his responses.==20Ben---
